text: so today i'm going to be talking about a series of studies that we conducted at yahoo labs trying to understand mobile
use and if you've seen some of my other talks in the past this is sort of very different this isn't where we've built things and
we're running field studies of them and seeing how people use them this is really understanding what people are
doing today with all of the different devices that they have in their lives and so i'll take you through three
different studies that we ran and try to bring that all together in the end
so as michael said i'm at the hci research lab at yahoo where i've been for a few years now and i've been in
corporate research now for 14 years really kind of seeing this evolution of mobile technology
in various ways and i do teach out at mit we started a mobile hci class back in 2006. so if you remember like iphone
dates and android dates that's pre-modern smartphone and we had students designing developing and
running field trials of unique mobile apps back then and still teach it which makes
for really crazy tuesdays flying back and forth to boston
so why mobile why is this a topic that we should study as hci researchers well
there's 7.1 billion active mobile cell phones right now and that is a huge number um that's 98
of the population but obviously there's duplicates some people have two phones or three phones or four phones but that
number is massive this is a technology that everyone is using in their daily lives every day
and you know a good chunk of those connections are on fast 3g 4g networks
where rich applications and services can really fit into people's daily lives
and mobile is everywhere but it's also still growing so even with that 7.1 billion
number um these are the graphs this is you know how android is taking off how ios is taking off and still selling
hundreds and hundreds of millions of units you know every year so mobile is everywhere it's still
growing and it's growing to become a bigger part of our day as well this past year people are now spending
more time with the phone lit interacting on their phone for than they are watching television so
people are spending over three hours a day or almost three hours a day two hours and 57 minutes a day with the
screen on interacting with their cell phones um and you know it's you can watch that graph of it rise just in the
past couple years in 2012 it was only 109 minutes and now it's up to 177. so
the time we're spending on these devices is growing exponentially but
what are people doing on their phones what are people doing for those three hours a day that the screen is lit and
their face is planted in their phone that's really where this research started and how can we understand how
phones are actually fitting into people's lives today so i'll talk about a series of studies
these studies combine quantitative and qualitative methods and we really want to use them
to triangulate on practices really understand not only what people are doing but why they're doing it and how
these devices fit into their lives the studies i'll talk about are also somewhat longitudinal in nature they
definitely are more than just a single interview or a single data collection point they usually off comprise multiple
interviews some diary logging some loggers we install on their devices to really understand use over some period
of time and we had a ton of research questions when we started this work really just from the very basic how are people using
their devices what apps are they using how do they manage different communication apps in their lives you
know how how are phones and tablets used with television so while you're watching tv what are you doing on your mobile
phones because we know that people are using their phones a lot while they're watching tv and then we had some
questions around people's social phone books so the phone book on your phone these days is not just the short list of
people you call it's really an aggregate of all of your contacts from everywhere on the web facebook google yahoo
linkedin whatever services you have really all integrate into most modern phone books right now and so we had a
lot of questions about what what those comprise and what those lists could be good for in
mobile applications so why are we doing this part of it is the academic side we are
interested in understanding for society how phones are impacting people's lives and what it
means to have these new devices relatively new devices that have come out in the last few years that people
are spending three hours a day staring at but i also work for a company and so
obviously yahoo has a lot of interest in understanding this as well we are
primarily a mobile app company now we have 500 million people every month using our mobile apps and so we want to
improve those apps we want to understand um for contextual app recommendation in
apps like aviate our home screen how can we get you the right app suggestion to launch at the right time
we have large mobile search initiatives at yahoo and how can we help you find the right information at the right time
or even push information to you before you even think to search for it we have a social phone book that's out
on android and some of the work that i'll talk about on the phone book helped shape that product and obviously we have
a lot of different content apps so understanding people's consumption of things like news sports and finance on
their mobile phone can help us improve those apps that yahoo makes and then going beyond just improving
what we have today a lot of this work can help build what's next and invent new future applications services and
even devices that better fit into people's daily lives and interactions
so i'll talk about three studies first i'll talk about a study we conducted with teens to understand how
mobile apps and mobile devices fit into their lives i'll talk about a study where we look at phone and tv
interaction and then talk about a study looking at the composition and use of mobile phone books
so before i dive into any particular study i want to talk about some of our methods that might be a little new to
some of you one of the big methods we use in a lot of our studies are app loggers
this is a piece of software we put on people's phones that keeps track of every app that's up on the screen and
exactly when it's on the screen we don't capture you know anything people type or exactly what they're doing but we can
see for example in this this example here they turned the display on they were on their home screen for five
seconds they went into facebook for 30 seconds they went back to their home screen for a second and then the display
went off so these app loggers can capture everything people do on their phones and tablets
at this level so we can see when they're launching apps how long they're using them and sequences of apps as well
another method that we commonly use in our studies are voicemail diaries so if you just ask someone in an interview to
recall things from the past there's often a lot of issues in remembering exactly what
happened at what time remembering counts of how often things happened or exactly the specific um
the specifics around a particular interaction so we have people during our study call into a voicemail either every
day every couple days once a week depending on the length of the study and just talk a little bit about how they've
been using their device or an application that we've given them to use so we can get data in the middle of the
study when it's fresh in their mind and they really remember what they did on their device
so we'll we'll talk about how we use those methods in each study but first we'll talk about this teen app study
this was with some of my colleagues at yahoo karen beverly kent and matt who is
an intern that we had from uc irvine and this was an 18-day study of how 14
diverse teens from all over the bay area used their mobile phone and we used a bunch of deep qualitative and
quantitative methods that i'll get to in a minute and we were really interested in how they were using communication
applications because this is a category of apps that we had presumed teens were using a lot and in developing new
communication apps at yahoo we really wanted to get an understanding of of what they were doing today
the study had five guys it had nine nine women in it
half were 13 to 15 half were 16 to 18 all over the wider bay area and they
were split between ios and android users the method itself we started with an
initial interview because they were teens we needed to get parental permission uh for them to participate in
the study we showed examples of exactly what we'd be collecting and made sure everyone was comfortable uh with what we
were about to do and we asked the participant about their existing phone use we put a logger on
their phone so we could keep track of the apps they were using over the next 18 days and then during those 18 days we had the
teen give us a call on an 800 number and just tell us about how they had been using their phone that day and then we
also had the logger that was keeping track of what they were doing and we had a final interview where we asked some follow-up questions based on the
voicemails trying to get more data about specific instances that maybe they were a little terse about or didn't talk
about exactly what we were interested in and had some more general questions around phone and social network use
so we collected these 18 days of logs and that comprised for these 14 teens 79
000 interaction events with the phone um and that included 34 000 app launches for
these 14 teens over over 18 days uh and these participants were using 271 unique
applications so they were just all over in terms of the apps they were using we'll go into
some more detail in a moment and then obviously we had all the qualitative data we had interview transcripts from
the initial and final interview and all of the voicemails we took all the qualitative data we did
a grounded theory based affinity analysis to find some themes in that data that emerged we'll be discussing
those themes here in the talk and really understanding deeply how they
were using these services and how they fit into their lives they were spending about three hours a
day interacting with their phone with the phone lit and over two hours a day in particular
applications so the other hour was time spent in the home screen or the settings or the
the lock screen on the phone and the average times in a particular app was about a minute
so these are very quick interactions and we'll give a breakdown in a minute of what some of the longer or shorter
app categories were but this this use is very bursty i mean every one minute in an app but they're
using apps 136 minutes a day which is quite a lot they were using a
lot of apps on average they had 36 unique apps and a range of 22 to 64. so
even the teen who was using the fewest apps was using 22 different apps in their lives over these over these two
weeks an average of 129 app launches a day um
and so that when you start to think about this this is a huge number 129
launches of particular applications and they were using 15 different app categories so things like social
networking news email all of those are in different app categories
so those are just some of the raw numbers but how did the use really fit into the pattern of the day
this is this is just the number of app launches in each hour so you can see for a lot of these teens they woke up pretty
early 6 7 a.m started using their devices but they get a huge spike after
school most high schoolers end school around 3 p.m and so you can see this huge spike in abuse coming at the end of
the school day and continuing you know well into the night to 10 pm or so and that's really their core interaction
time with the phone but what are they doing in those times so this is looking at different app
categories and when in the day people are using the apps so the blue at the top those are all the communication apps
and you can see that just 3 pm they start and they're communicating like crazy 3 pm to 10 pm that's really their
heavy use time for communications applications you can see some sort of obvious things
like the weather app gets used in the morning 6 7 a.m when they get up and then not used at all maybe a little bit
at the end of the day to check whether uh the education 6a um that was it's an
app that was actually not used very much i have another table that shows um numbers for each of these but the
education category was hardly ever used it could have been uh to check like this the uh grades or their schedule for the
school um but that was a category that was not used quite as much
i don't think it's many instances there's not that many instances that's what i'm saying so maybe it's an app that was launched five times or ten
times right it was launched six times at six am and four times at eight pm um
yeah but i have another table that can can show you some of the categories but i think the main things to take away
from this is you know communications is happening later in the day and some other categories are at
specific times like weather in the morning and things like that one of the things we were most intrigued
by was that the phone is still primarily a phone despite using these dozens of different apps every day the top apps
are sms and phone calls and you know even for teens who you think are using all these other communication
apps and they're not really using these core features of the phone um the core phone apps were the most used among the
teens and then you see the other kind of social apps instagram snapchat twitter facebook all of that appearing in the
middle here but the main apps are still the main phone apps
that's one launcher close it and open up it again that would count as two launches yeah yeah we'll also talk a little bit about
duration in a minute um but right now we're just talking about particular launches of the app which generally
means you're on the home screen and you hit the icon and it opens up the app
doesn't i mean don't you really mean visits because apps can live in the background and you
can just open it up again well we count that as a separate launch so yeah
yeah so revisiting an app is a separate logic yeah anytime that something else was on
the screen and then the app comes back then we're counting that as a launch whether it comes from the home screen or
the recent apps or a notification yeah you could have done yeah
um so if we start looking at durations of app use and here you can see some of the counts for each of the categories
but you can see that the apps that people are using for longer periods of time you can see games travel entertainment
media news magazines these are the apps that are you know the teens were spending two
three minutes in per interaction and you can see things like the contact
list uh the phone um email these were very short interactions uh certainly in
comparison to some of the media based interactions um that are that are towards the bottom
so this is looking how different categories of apps really fit into people's lives and here you can see by
category the social networking apps were more heavily used in the one to five minute range so if you think of
facebook kind of scrolling through the feed seeing everything if you think of instagram liking photos uploading your
own photos these are things that that would engage them for for much longer periods of time than really quick
interactions like with the contact list right most contact list interactions were less than five seconds you open it
you hit somebody that's near the top and you're done and you're in the phone book or you're in the you're in a phone call or you're in
an sms message so what we saw with these teens is it really is all about communication for
them two-thirds of their time spent in apps was spent in communication related apps and so these are just all the top
apps and you can see all of them except browsers and pandora are communication related apps
and this is really what they're using their phones for and they're using an average of 9.4 different communication
apps per participant in the study so they don't have just the go-to every
time they communicate it's sms they're using sms they're using instagram they're using snapchat they're using
twitter they're using facebook they're using all these different apps in their lives for different purposes and so that
was something we were really interested in digging into in the qualitative data james
the date of the study it was um late 2013 yeah
is there any um they think might be a big change from them and now or i would expect the usage
to even go up from then um if you look at the general phone
the distribution of apps i would expect facebook to fall even more even in our study the teens were already
telling us that's how i communicate with my aunt and uncle um and that's not how you know they would communicate with
their friends so i'd expect that to fall a little more
i would expect maybe whatsapp to start to show up here where it wasn't showing up at all in late 2013 but i still
expect the percentage of communication apps to probably stay about the same um and that's really what they what they
were doing with the the bulk of their time so as i said we were really interested in the qualitative data and digging in
why are they using particular apps and snapchat was something we were particularly interested in because it
was very much on the rise in 2013 when we ran the study and we ran it towards the end of 2013 um so we got we
were asking teens a lot about why they were using it what they were doing with it and they would tell us that
they don't want a history and they don't they want some way where they can just feel like they're sharing something with
a friend no one's going to record it and it will just go away and so you know
someone one of the participants told the snapchat is so temporary i don't care what the picture is of it's my closest
friends you know we send ugly pictures of ourselves we make funny faces we do something stupid and the teens don't
feel that there's any repercussion for capturing that and sharing it with each other
and that leads into why they're not using facebook as much um our participant two told us i don't use
facebook it leads to too many problems in your life you post one thing on there it's never going to go away um and they
really feel that you know even if they try to manage who can see it someone will end up seeing it because some
setting is not configured right or somebody will forward it beyond their control and they really feel that using
that platform could get them in trouble later in life and these kind of goofy pictures they're sending to each other
um could be used against them and that's something that probably has been drilled into them by teachers and parents and be
careful what you put online and that's one reason that these these categories of applications that are much more
ephemeral and don't keep a lasting profile are becoming more popular for them
and we see that for sites that have a lasting profile these teens were taking so much effort to craft the perfect post
and to get the perfect picture together p12 was on the softball team in her high school and they were all taking pictures
during this one game and they got together after the game and spent like half an hour putting a collage together
and getting all the right pictures and getting them at the right angles and getting everything that where everyone
looks perfect in the picture and she was also telling us we're just like well what did you do with the other pictures
and she's like oh yeah we snapchatted those back and forth like crazy ones where they were all muddy and dirty and looking looking not the way they wanted
to portray themselves on instagram or on facebook so that was really interesting to us how
how much effort they put into crafting something that was perfect to put out there for other people to see and they
would also tell us if they posted a photo and nobody liked it within a few minutes they would take it down
and multiple teens in the study were telling us about this practice how if you don't get that immediate social
validation you don't want the embarrassment of having a photo that has no likes and so they spend so much
effort crafting it and then if it doesn't hit it it's gone and they'll remove it almost immediately
in fact one of the participants she's like yeah my friend called me and said i really need to take my picture down
because it's been up too long and nobody's liking it and so even their friends were watching out for them you
know nobody's liking your photo make sure you take it away um and that was just this amazing behavior that that we
heard again and again from our participants the other thing we saw is snapchatting being used in in a mass communication
way and multiple of our participants were using it this way as well they would take a picture this one participant was
going off to college and she was packing to go down to la and she took this photo of her room kind of all empty because
she had put everything in her suitcase and mass snapchatted it and that's the word she used for this behavior
to everybody to anyone she had friended on snapchat so she didn't want to post
it to facebook she's like it's just that's too much but she just wanted a bunch of people to see it and just have
it go away and not kind of have that memory of the empty home lingering around on the internet
another thing we looked at was coordination and what apps the teens were using to coordinate with each other
most of the time they were using sms because that's an app everyone has if you have an iphone if you have an
android it doesn't matter you can sms with each other you know it's going to get through at least you're pretty confident it's
going to get through and it works with everyone one of the other things we saw is these are teens they get their phones taken
away by their parents and many of them had ipod touches that they were allowed to use if their phone
got taken away and so they would use kik then the whole group would switch to kik for the duration that their friend had
their phone taken away because they could use kik without a sim card um and some parents would actually just steal
the sim card from their kids phones and not actually take away the phone so it would still work on wi-fi um and then
they would switch to kik because they don't have you know the sms capability on the phone
and we talked to them a bit about phone calls and again and again the participants were like yeah that's you
know if you have an objective to complete you will make a phone call if your mom is supposed to pick you up and
she's not there you make a phone call or if you need to plan an exact arrival time of something you make a phone call
but for the most part the phone for the the actual phone you talk on for these participants was
sort of a not something they would just do on a regular basis they weren't calling each
other and talking to each other on the phone very much sometimes they'd use skype they'd do group skypes videos hangouts things like
that but they weren't actually spending much time chatting on the phone with each other
another theme that came out of our analysis was using the phone just to pass time and feeling like you almost
have this compulsion to keep using the phone and you know i'm walking home alone i'm bored i'm just going to play
games or text people you know if you're bored you can go watch netflix things like that that the phone was just this
this device that could fill the the the spare time that they had and could really just kind of grow to fill
whatever amount of time they had where they weren't interacting with others or working on their schoolwork and things
like that but they were actually very aware that they were spending a lot of time on their phone and we asked one of
our participants about games and she's like oh i never play candy crush i was tempted to but my roommate lost her life
doing that she's on it all the time it's so addicting and so so participants in
the study really knew that there were some things that probably they should stay away from and might really
end up taking too much of their time and distracting so key takeaways from this study the
teens were using their phones about three hours a day which was ahead of the general population at that time you know
a year and a few months ago specific apps are more common at certain times of day or at certain locations
the teens are very actively considering the ephemerality in the audience when they're choosing a communication service
it's not that they just have a go-to app and that's how they communicate they really think what is this going to
reflect on me in the future and they will spend a lot of time crafting a
perfect post for something that's going to have a profile where they can just use snapchat to share these moments with
each other i'm curious what the distribution of behaviors was amongst the teens like did you find that most
teens were using it around three hours a day or was there a wide variety in the amount of time people were spending on
their phone to what they're doing it's actually it was quite uniform i think the lowest was like
don't quote me on the particular numbers but i feel like the lowest was around like 1.8 hours a day or so and then we
had somebody who was up around four but it was yeah it was within that range they were all really using their phones
quite a lot and you know maybe day to day it varies or weekday weekend it varies a little bit but they were all very much tied to
their devices we also saw that you know teens are frequently rebuilding new networks on
new services instead of curating lists on existing services we talked to them a bit about you know like how do you would
you ever defriend people or like no no we just moved to the next app so you know they'll move to snapchat and
build a new network on snapchat and then they don't have to worry about curating the network they had on facebook that they don't really use anymore
which was quite interesting to us and they desire communication platforms that anyone can use regardless of device and
that's why sms is still the number one app among every teen in our study sms was their go-to communication app
so moving on a bit from teens we just finished another study this fall looking at combined phone tablet use
with television and you know the second screen and using mobile devices uh while
watching tv has become a big media buzzword recently um
twitter is being heavily promoted during television shows mainly because networks want you to watch it live which means
you watch the commercials but they're heavily promoting the use of hashtags and the use of twitter during
tv programming and there are survey studies that show people report using their mobile devices
a lot while they watch tv but there's really not much data on what exactly they're doing beyond people
checking a box like i use it for shopping or i use it for email or i use it for for these categories of things
so we wanted to investigate this we wanted to see what phone and tablet use
looks like during tv watching how often are people using their devices are there differences when the programs are on and
when the commercials are on are there differences between different genres what apps are used most frequently when
people are watching tv and then why are they doing this um is it that the tv show isn't compelling
enough to keep their full attention are they using it during commercials or lulls in the shows to keep themselves
busy um you know why why is this this phenomena really happening
so this was a bit of a complex setup um because we wanted to unders we wanted to capture all of this data to really have
a ground truth of what they were doing so yahoo is a service called into now it's basically like shazam but for tv
shows um so we took a mobile phone and we just put it underneath their television and so this was listening
to the ambient audio in the room and it would on device capture a fingerprint
that it would then try to match on the server so we weren't storing any raw audio or anything of what was going on in the living room but it was capturing
a fingerprint every 30 seconds of what they were watching on tv if it was a commercial if it was a tv show what show
it was um so we had a ground truth of tv watching in the home and then we placed ble bluetooth low energy beacons
throughout the home and our app logger on the phone we modified to look at the
signal strength to the ble beacons and so now we knew what room of the home they were in with fairly high accuracy
and if they were home or if they were away from the home so we would know you're in the living room the tv is on you're watching this
show and you're using these particular apps on your phone so bit of a complex setup but it got us
all the data that we needed and the the study was structured much like the previous one we had an initial
interview we set up everything in their home for two weeks we had them have a voicemail diary just about how they were
using their devices we didn't ask for a specific um commentary around television
use we were hoping that that would come out a bit naturally from the data and then we had a final
interview where we asked questions and follow-ups based on the logs and based on the voicemails that we got
so what did we what did we get we captured a bunch of phone use a bunch of tablet use
we saw that half of all phone use was at home and that eighteen percent of phone use
at home was while watching television uh which is a was was fairly interesting to us we we captured all the shows they
were watching uh they were watching uh about 21 of their shows were 30 minutes long a little bit more were one hour
long shows a variety of genres so we feel like we collected a nice amount of data
that we could then start looking at so when did they interact we were
expecting to see big spikes in phone use during commercials this is what people often
self-report doing but we actually did not see that at all we saw very little difference actually
between phone use during programs and phone use during commercials
and this could be because you know people are other you know they use the commercial times to go to the kitchen or go to the
bathroom or go do other things um but um we found that quite interesting we also found it interesting that 25 of
the time the tv is on they're using their phone and tablet so that is a significant amount of the
tv program where they are engaged on a second device and presumably not watching the tv as much
we saw some differences in genres so comedy drama sports
events or non-events not events or things like sportscenter or things like that people were using their devices quite a
lot of the time 60 70 percent of the time while that show was on some device was
being used um whereas the more like documentary science news magazine
history nature things like that um the device was not being used as much and so
that was was fairly interesting to us that those those shows that you kind of have to pay attention to because they're
actually telling you something informative um you're not actually interacting with the device as much uh
whereas things like sports where you could zone out for half an hour and not missed something maybe in a soccer match
you know people were very heavily engaged with their devices and we'll get into some of the motivations for for using it in a moment john did you have a
question whether you accounted for multiple people watching tv and multiple
devices like sometimes i'm on my phone while my wife's watching something.tv were you able to take that
in the data well yes and we'll talk quite a bit about that in the qualitative data and that is one reason
that the use is so high is people are not interested in the show at all but they want to be with their family member
who is watching something that they care about um more on that in like three slides um one thing that we found was
really interesting was these looking at reality shows and crime dramas these are
shows where something big happens at the end someone gets kicked off they find the
murderer someone's convicted right the phone use which are the bars drops
substantially for the last 10 minutes of the show um for both crime dramas and
reality shows so people are kind of zoning out they're doing their thing while the show is on and then in the last 10 minutes they put their phone
down and they're like okay what's gonna happen like this is the interesting part of the show um so we found that to be to
be quite interesting in looking at what they were doing but that's a lot on what and the
quantitative but why are they doing this um and here's to john's point
repeatedly people were telling us i want to be in the same room as my family member they're they're really excited
about survivor i hate it but i want to be with them right so i'm going to sit on the couch with them and i'm going to
play on my tablet or i'm going to play on my phone or i'm going to do the bills or i'm going to do something but i want
to be seated next to them and that we heard that again and again and again from our participants is they
were not actively watching the show it was someone else in the household who was really excited about it
um we also saw people like doing chores paying bills
things like that during the show and we saw all the other times where the tv was just background noise and this is you
know known in tv literature the tv is often on in the home and nobody's really watching and we saw this around sporting
events sometimes you know this one participant says oh i'm watching basketball i can hear what's going on i
don't have to be looking at it you know the announcer will start to get excited in his voice if something's about to
happen and i'll look up um so they can be doing something else on their phone and just kind of hearing the game um
and other people said you know if i wasn't particularly engaged in whatever we're watching you know i'm checking email on my phone when i'm doing other
things so the tv program is often not the focus of attention and
it's just kind of there as some background to have something going on in the home we found that very little of their
device use was actually related to the show they were watching so this is something that all the second screen
hype is you know you're interacting with people on twitter you're talking about the show you're looking up brands you're
doing all of this stuff related to the program now this doesn't really happen um it happens to some amount but this
isn't the majority of use the majority of use is facebook and and and email and
texting and just sort of the standard mundane phone usage but we did see a few instances
this one person was watching a razorback's game and they didn't have the stat he wanted to see he was a big sports guy he wanted a stat at this
moment in the show and it wasn't in the broadcast so he took out his phone and he opened up the cbs sports app and
found the stat he was looking for other people who had fantasy sports teams were often checking the fantasy
team and their score in the fantasy team as things went on as well and we did find one example of shopping
uh there was a commercial that showed a car that this this little toy car that her daughter really liked and they
actually went online and found it and bought it like within a few minutes of the commercial happening um so this kind
of stuff does happen people do get inspired by what's going on on the tv and they go off and find something but
you know i we really had to hunt to find these examples to actually talk about related things people were doing um it's
really often these these non-related uses that that are occurring so some of the implications from this
study um first of all understanding people and their behaviors is is really interesting in its own right um you know
television is such a big part of our lives three hours a day now phones are a big part of our lives three hours a day
how do those work together how are how is the act of watching television changing now that we have these mobile
devices and you might argue that well somebody else might have just taken the newspaper or the magazine and sat on the
